item.title: Spain Scrutinizes Break in Track After 2 Trains Collide, Killing 40
item.description: Crews were working to retrieve bodies after two high-speed trains derailed in southern Spain. The regional authorities said 41 people were hospitalized, with a dozen of them in intensive care.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Syria Struggles to Rebuild a Year After the Assad Regime’s Fall
item.description: A year after the dictator fell, Syrians are returning to a country with no clear plan for rebuilding.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Saad Alnassife and Nicole Tung
item.category: Destruction of Cultural Antiquities and Heritage

item.title: Trump Links His Push for Greenland to Not Winning Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: In a text, President Trump told Norway’s prime minister that he no longer felt obliged to “think purely of Peace” and that the U.S. needed the island for global security.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Store of Norway during a meeting last year.

item.title: Trump Is Pushing the U.S.-Europe Alliance to the Brink Over Greenland
item.description: As President Trump tries to coerce European leaders over Greenland, they are pondering the unthinkable: Is an 80-year-old alliance doomed?
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with European leaders at the White House in August. On Saturday, Mr. Trump said he would raise tariffs on several European countries unless they let him acquire Greenland.

item.title: Slow Emergency Response Blamed in Deadly Pakistan Mall Fire
item.description: The blaze, which killed at least 23 and left dozens more missing during “wedding season,” burned all night and day through a Karachi plaza with hundreds of shops.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:credit: Akhtar Soomro/Reuters
item.media:description: The ruins of the Gul Plaza Shopping Mall in Karachi, Pakistan, on Monday. The source of the blaze during a busy weekend was unconfirmed.

item.title: Splits Emerge Among Venezuelans as Revolutionary Dream Fades
item.description: Supporters of former president Hugo Chávez, the anti-American socialist, are struggling to come to terms with their government’s pact with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators demanding the release of President Nicolás Maduro in Caracas, Venezuela, on Friday.

item.title: Clashes Erupt Around Syrian Prisons Holding Islamic State Fighters
item.description: New tensions flared a day after a Kurdish-led militia agreed to hand over control of prisons holding some 8,000 Islamic State fighters to the Syrian government.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Baderkhan Ahmad/Associated Press
item.media:description: Soldiers of the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces deployed near the Gweiran Prison, which houses men accused of being Islamic State fighters, in Hasakah Province, northeastern Syria, on Monday.

item.title: At the Center of Trump’s Vision for Rebuilding Ukraine: BlackRock
item.description: The world’s largest asset manager has been enlisted to help build Ukraine’s recovery plan. Some fear it is part of a Trump administration effort to steer the effort toward American business interests.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mezhova, in eastern Ukraine, in December. Ukrainian officials have likened their country’s recovery blueprint to the Marshall Plan, the U.S.-funded project to rebuild Europe after World War II.

item.title: What to Know About Hezbollah’s Ties to Venezuela
item.description: U.S. authorities have accused Hezbollah of complicity in drug trafficking and money laundering schemes in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters at the Lebanon-Syria border in 2017.

item.title: Gaza’s Board of Peace: What to Know
item.description: Numerous countries say they have been invited to join President Trump’s newly minted organization, which critics say could undermine the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gaza City in December.

item.title: Sanae Takaichi, Japan’s Prime Minister, Calls for Snap Election
item.description: Sanae Takaichi, the first woman to be Japan’s prime minister, is hoping to seize on her popularity by calling a parliamentary election next month.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Kiyoshi Ota
item.media:description: Sanae Takaichi, the prime minister of Japan, called early elections just three months into her tenure.

item.title: French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu Says He Will Pass Budget Without a Vote
item.description: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu’s effort to force the measure through Parliament opened up his government to a vote of no confidence.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Sarah Meyssonnier/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu in the National Assembly in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Prince Harry’s Court Case Against Daily Mail Publisher: What to Know
item.description: A trial began on Monday in Harry’s case accusing Associated Newspapers of phone hacking and other unlawful activities. Other claimants include Elton John and Liz Hurley.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:credit: Kin Cheung/Associated Press
item.media:description: Prince Harry leaving the High Court in London after giving evidence. He has pursued several legal battles aimed at holding Britain’s tabloids to account over unlawful news gathering.

item.title: What Vietnam’s Communist Party Congress Hopes to Achieve
item.description: One of Asia’s most dynamic nations is weighing how to balance government control with raising per capita G.D.P. by about 70 percent in five years.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Tung Ngo
item.media:credit: Nhac Nguyen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Signage for the 14th Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam outside the National Convention Center in Hanoi this month.

item.title: The Chinese Island Where Dreams of Real Estate Glory Never Die
item.description: Intended as China’s version of Dubai’s palm-shaped artificial island, Ocean Flower Island is a $12 billion monument to debt-fueled economic excess.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Gilles Sabrié

item.title: Death Toll Rises in Guatemalan Gang Riots
item.description: Uprisings in three prisons have killed 10 police officers, presenting another challenge for President Bernardo Arévalo in his fight against corruption and organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Jody García, James Wagner and Daniele Volpe
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ceremony to honor eight police officers who died in attacks by gang members the day before, on Monday in Guatemala City.

item.title: Taxing the Ultrarich
item.description: The number of billionaires has exploded, yet they often pay taxes at rates well below average.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times

item.title: How 40 People Died In a Train Crash in Andalucia, Spain
item.description: The victims of Spain’s deadliest rail crash in more than a decade included a police officer, journalists and a family returning from a musical.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, José Bautista and Samuel Granados
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency officials at the scene of the crash on Monday.

item.title: A labor union raised concerns last year about Spain’s railway lines.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Susana Vera/Reuters
item.media:description: Members of the Spanish Civil Guard, along with other emergency personnel, work next to one of the trains involved in the accident, in Cordoba, Spain, on Monday.

item.title: The crash occurred on a new stretch of high-speed rail track, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Jorge Guerrero/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A train operated by Iryo, a private company, that partially derailed and was hit by another train on Monday near Adamuz, in southern Spain.

item.title: Survivors of Deadly Train Crash in Spain Describe Hellish Scenes
item.description: Photographs show a tangled mess of metal, wires and broken glass at the scene of the crash, which killed at least 39 people.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, Samuel Granados and José Bautista
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Spanish Civil Guard, along with other emergency personnel, working next to one of the trains involved in the accident in Adamuz on Monday.

item.title: Trump Has an Offramp on Greenland. He Doesn’t Seem to Want It.
item.description: The strategic importance of Greenland is growing, and NATO has underinvested in Arctic security. But President Trump, intent on ownership, is rebuffing deals with Europe to solve the problem.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: For President Trump, the sheer size of Greenland’s territory holds part of the appeal; it is about three times the size of Texas, and bigger than Alaska.

item.title: Human Rights Lawyer Philippe Sands Fears a New Age of Impunity
item.description: Philippe Sands, one of the world’s pre-eminent human rights attorneys, grew up in the shadow of bleak times. He worries that history is taking an unfortunate detour.
item.dc:creator: Michael Steinberger
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
38 Londres Street: On Impunity, Pinochet in England, and a Nazi in Patagonia (Book)
item.media:credit: Nadav Kander for The New York Times

item.title: I.M.F. Raises Forecast for Global Growth as Tariff Drag Fades
item.description: The 3.3 percent rate for 2026 would match last year’s pace. Booming investment in artificial intelligence is buttressing global output.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exhibit at a conference held by Nvidia, which makes chips that power artificial intelligence. Surging investment in technology is poised this year to offset the headwinds of rising protectionism.

item.title: Spain Closes High-Speed Rail Network in South After Crash
item.description: The closures were announced after a high-speed train derailed and smashed into another high-speed train, killing at least 39 people and injuring dozens.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Carlos Luján/Europa Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Passengers at a train station in Madrid on Sunday, after the train derailment in southern Spain.

item.title: As Davos Convenes, Deference to Trump Has Replaced Everything
item.description: The traditional rhetoric of the World Economic Forum centered on global integration, climate change and international cooperation. Not anymore.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:credit: Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Attendees at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, last year.

item.title: Why Are New Zealanders Moving to Australia? More Money, Better Vibes.
item.description: More than 1 percent of New Zealand’s population left over the year ending in October. Many of the migrants were chasing salaries and opportunities in neighboring Australia.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Tatsiana Chypsanava
item.media:description: Travelers at Wellington International Airport, in New Zealand last month.

item.title: What We Know About the Deadly High-Speed Train Crash in Spain
item.description: The train crash in the southern region of Andalucía on Sunday was the deadliest in Spain since at least 2013.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim
item.media:credit: Alex Gallegos/Reuters
item.media:description: A person affected by a deadly train derailment was transferred for treatment to the Caseta Municipal in Adamuz, Spain, on Sunday.

item.title: Guatemala Declares State of Emergency to Address Gang Violence
item.description: The country has seen a surge of unrest in recent days, including uprisings at prisons and the killing of police officers, which the authorities have blamed on gangs.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Edwin Bercian/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Guatemalan riot police officers guard the entrance to the men’s Preventive Detention Center in Guatemala City on Sunday.

item.title: Real Estate Crash Weighs on China’s Economic Growth
item.description: Falling apartment prices have erased the savings of millions of Chinese households, but exports lifted the economy to 5 percent growth last year.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: China is still grappling with a property market crash that began four years ago, after many years of overbuilding.

item.title: European Union Officials Lean Toward Negotiating, Not Retaliating, Over Trump Tariff Threat
item.description: European Union ambassadors held an emergency meeting on Sunday, and leaders from across the 27-nation bloc will meet in Brussels later this week.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: The flag of Greenland flying outside the Danish Parliament on Friday.

item.title: High-Speed Train Crash in Spain Leaves at Least 21 Dead
item.description: A high-speed train smashed into another train after derailing in the southern province of Córdoba, officials said. The cause of the accident was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, José Bautista and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: via Reuters

item.title: Trump’s Ultimatum to Europe
item.description: Trump threatened heavy tariffs on countries standing between him and Greenland. E.U. leaders are scrambling for a response.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times

item.title: Chile Wildfires Kill 16 and Force Wide Evacuation
item.description: One mayor pleaded with the national government for help as flames destroyed entire neighborhoods in the southern region of Biobío.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and John Bartlett
item.media:credit: Juan Gonzalez/Reuters
item.media:description: Buildings damaged by wildfires in Chile’s Biobío region on Sunday.

item.title: Syrian Government and Kurdish-Led Force Agree to Merge After Clashes
item.description: The new deal also calls for a cease-fire. Government forces have taken strategic assets from the militia in recent days, weakening the force.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Karam Almasri/Reuters
item.media:description: Syrian Army personnel celebrated as government forces entered the northern city of Raqqa on Sunday.

item.title: Danes Feel Betrayed and Bewildered by Trump Amid Greenland Threats
item.description: The American president’s vow to get Greenland, the semiautonomous Danish territory, has thrown the tiny, pro-American Nordic nation into crisis.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Bumiller and Hilary Swift
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators gather at Råduspladsen, City Hall in Copenhagen on Saturday. People gathered in different cities in Denmark and Greenland to protest against US President Donald Trump’s designs to take over the Arctic island. The timing coinsided with a US delegations trip to Copenhagen.

item.title: $1 Billion in Cash Buys a Permanent Seat on Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’
item.description: The board was originally conceived to oversee the rebuilding of Gaza, but its charter does not mention the Palestinian enclave, suggesting a possibly broader mandate.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gaza City, last week. About 80 percent of the buildings in Gaza have been damaged or destroyed, according to the United Nations.

item.title: After Trump Reignites a Trade War Over Greenland, Europe Weighs Hitting Back
item.description: Europe’s dependence on the United States for NATO security limits its options. Its strongest response would be a trade “bazooka,” and other options are possible.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Juliette Pavy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against President Trump in Nuuk, the capital of Greenland, on Saturday.

item.title: The Biggest Challenge in Venezuela Is Soaring Food Prices
item.description: Economic instability in Venezuela after the U.S. raid to capture its president is deepening inflation and rattling the currency, sending grocery bills soaring for millions of people.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova, Camille Rodríguez Montilla and Isayen Herrera
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman showing her nearly empty refrigerator in Los Teques, Venezuela.

item.title: At Davos, Global Leaders Gather to Ponder the Future of a Messy World
item.description: At its 56th annual meeting in Davos, the World Economic Forum will wrestle with war, economics, artificial intelligence and other pressing issues.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.category: Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs
item.media:credit: UGC, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of Iranians have taken to the streets during the latest uprising, including an anti-government protest in Tehran.

item.title: Can Davos Help Protect the Planet?
item.description: The World Economic Forum, which takes place in Switzerland, aims to meet at least some of the goals its leaders set for the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora
item.media:credit: Denis Balibouse/Reuters
item.media:description: The town of Davos, Switzerland, site of the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting. Over the years, the event’s organizers have been working to reduce the environmental impact of the meeting.

item.title: Avalanches Across Austrian Alps Kill 8 Skiers in One Day
item.description: Skiers have also died from avalanche-related accidents in the Swiss and French Alps over the past week.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Markus Schreiber/Bergrettung Pongau, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo provided by the mountain rescue service in the Pongau region of Austria shows rescuers searching for avalanche victims on Saturday.

item.title: How a Screwdriver Salesman Helped Fuel U.S. Airstrikes in Nigeria
item.description: Spotty research from a Christian activist has been used by Republican lawmakers to justify U.S. intervention in the country.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emeka Umeagbalasi, 56, at his home in Onitsha, Nigeria, last month.

item.title: Chimney Sweeps Are Making a Comeback in the U.K. as Energy Costs Climb
item.description: The centuries-old trade is enjoying something of a revival, partly driven by rising energy costs. Today’s sweeps use new tools and technology.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Josh Firkins, left, and Tom Joslin, an apprentice, sweeping a chimney last month in London.

item.title: France’s Embassy in Iraq Is a Spoil of Antisemitism, Jewish Family Charges
item.description: A Jewish family that fled Iraq generations ago rented its home to France for use as an embassy, but Paris long ago stopped paying it rent, after Iraq stripped Jews of property.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: Lawee and Khazzam families
item.media:description: An aerial view of the house built by Ezra and Khedouri Lawee in the 1930s.

item.title: Greenlanders Protest Trump’s Takeover Plans
item.description: Protests erupted in several Greenlandic cites and in Denmark as President Trump intensified his efforts to take control of the Arctic island.
item.dc:creator: Maya Tekeli and Juliette Pavy
item.media:credit: Juliette Pavy for The New York Times

item.title: Syria Advance on Kurdish-Held Areas as Washington Urges Restraint
item.description: Government troops drew closer to Raqqa, the largest city overseen by the Kurds, raising U.S. concerns about the renewal of a wider conflict in the region.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Syrian government forces launching a rocket toward Kurdish forces near Dibsi Faraj in northern Syria on Saturday.

item.title: World Leaders Consider Joining Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’ for Gaza
item.description: The clash came as world leaders were deciding whether to join President Trump’s “Board of Peace” for Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A camp for displaced Palestinians, in Gaza City, on Tuesday.

item.title: Prize Fight
item.description: In the run-up to the Oscar nominations, a chat with a reporter who has followed every twist and turn of the race.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Uganda’s President Museveni Is Declared Election Winner
item.description: Bobi Wine, the main opposition candidate, accused the government of vote rigging and has called for street protests.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Uganda’s president, Yoweri Museveni, has ruled the country for four decades.

item.title: Mr. Carney Goes to Beijing
item.description: The trip, a whirlwind of meetings with Chinese industry and top government officials, conveyed how the prime minister is viewing the wider world.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Sean Kilpatrick
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney with Xi Jinping, China’s top leader.

item.title: Can Cuba Survive Without Venezuela’s Oil?
item.description: President Trump stopped Venezuelan oil shipments to Cuba, and experts say disaster looms. Oil fuels its electric grid and without alternative supplies the country will plunge into extended darkness.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Norlys Perez/Reuters
item.media:description: A Cuban-flagged oil tanker anchored near the Matanzas terminal this month in Cuba.

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader, Unbending Over Time
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has built his 37-year rule on uncompromising repression. His answer to the current protests is no different.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei in 2024 in Tehran.

item.title: Despite Maduro’s Capture, Venezuelan Exiles Realize They’re Not Going Home Soon
item.description: Spain is home to the biggest collection of Venezuelan emigrants outside the Americas. Many cheered the capture of Nicolás Maduro, but are now adapting to the fact that his allies remain in charge.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, José Bautista and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The handsome Salamanca streets, a neighborhood in Madrid known as Little Caracas, and frequented by Venezuela’s wealthy, oil rich diaspora, last week.

item.title: Inside the Doctors Without Borders Clinics That Israel Is Closing in Gaza
item.description: The aid group has refused to comply with new Israeli rules restricting speech and demanding information on staff. Patients are stunned. “I need this place,” says one.
item.dc:creator: Bilal Shbair, David M. Halbfinger, Aaron Boxerman and Saher Alghorra
item.media:description: Aseel Hamada, 24, awaiting a physical therapy appointment at a Doctors Without Borders clinic in Gaza City.

item.title: How Wall Street Turned Its Back on Climate Change
item.description: Six years after the financial industry pledged to use trillions to fight climate change and reshape finance, its efforts have largely collapsed.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Climate activists protest BlackRock in New York City in 2023.

item.title: Is the Russian Military Adapting Effectively to the Drone Age?
item.description: Current and former commanders, analysts and military bloggers are having a surprisingly open debate about whether drones have made Russia’s longstanding approach to battle obsolete.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A damaged Russian tank near the village of Sulyhivka, in the eastern Ukrainian region of Kharkiv, in 2023. Ukraine increasingly relies on drones to neutralize Russian armor.

item.title: How a Play Skewering Modern Russia Evaded a Crackdown to Become a Hit
item.description: Everyone expected “The Kholops,” a drama exploring oppression, to be shut down soon after it opened in St. Petersburg. Instead, it is two years into a sold-out run.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
